Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
NAICS Translation: 424940: Tobacco and Tobacco Product Merchant Wholesalers
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: The country's two biggest tobacco companies agreed to improve public access to internal tobacco-industry documents and to pay $6.25 million into a court fund that will go to support the country's largest online collection of tobacco documents. The agreement was part of the landmark case against the country's largest cigarette companies.

Company: SANTA FE NATURAL TOBACCO COMPANY, INC.
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: Brown & Williamson agreed to pay $150 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging that it was not properly calculating the amount it owed the states under the 1998 tobacco industry Master Settlement Agreement.

The attorneys general of New York,  Maryland and Illinois announced that Brown & Williamson Tobacco Co. would pay $1.46 million as part of the settlement of litigation concerning the illegal marketing of Kool cigarettes to minors.

Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. were ordered to pay approximately $8.1 million in judgment of charges it made cigarettes for a third party that it did not pay the state for as required under the tobacco settlement agreement.

R.J.Reynolds and Brown and Williamson agreed to pay a total of $15 million in settlement of allegations they violated the terms of the tobacco settlement agreement by failing to pay into the fund for cigarettes manufactured for Star Tobacco. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the payment was divided equally between them.

R.J.Reynolds and Brown and Williamson agreed to pay a total of $15 million in settlement of allegations they violated the terms of the tobacco settlement agreement by failing to pay into the fund for cigarettes manufactured for Star Tobacco. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the payment was divided equally between them.

R.J. Reynolds agreed to pay $175,000 to allegations brought by California and Arizona that the company violated the terms of the Master Settlement Agreement (MSA) and state consumer protection laws in its mailing of free cigarettes to Californians.

R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. agreed to pay $150,000 in settlement of allegations its advertising spread in a 2007 Rolling Stone magazine violated the master tobacco settlement's ban on cartoons in cigarette advertising.
R.J. Reynolds Tobacco agreed to pay $17.25 million to settle a state lawsuit concerning its advertisements in publications with large teenage readership.

R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed to pay $5 million to resolve a lawsuit in which the California Supreme Court found RJR liable for violating state law when it distributed 108,155 free packs of cigarettes on public grounds.
R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company was ordered to pay almost $15 million in fines for illegally handing out more than 100,000 free packs of cigarettes at events where children were present.

The Florida Attorney General prevailed in a long-running court battle with R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company concerning millions of dollars owed to the state through the landmark tobacco settlement agreement.

Agency: North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality
